subject: RUSS
title: Fourth-Year Russian I
description: 8-week program: based on the Yale campus (New Haven, CT) for 3-weeks followed by 5-weeks in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring a semester’s worth of language study at the fourth-year level of Russian. Students who wish to apply need to first contact Professor Constantine Muravnik. Prerequisite: RUSS 151 (Third-Year Russian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S242. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from St. Petersburg and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the http://studyabroad.yale.edu/programs/fourth-year-russian-i-culture program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: RUSS
title: Russian Culture
description: 8-week program: based on the Yale campus (New Haven, CT) for 3-weeks followed by 5-weeks in St. Petersburg, Russia. An interdisciplinary and hands-on exploration of Russian cultural history in its transformations from the early 18th Century to the present through literature, visual arts and architecture, religion, social and political thought. Topics include conceptions of Russian nationhood; the myths of Moscow and St. Petersburg; dissent and persecution; elites, intelligentsia and attitudes toward the common people (narod); conflicting appeals of rationality, spirituality, and idealism. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS S130 & RUSS S140, or RUSS S150 & RUSS S151, or RUSS S160. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from St. Petersburg and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the http://studyabroad.yale.edu/programs program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: S&DS
title: Introduction to Statistics
description: An introduction to statistical reasoning. Topics include controlled experiments and observational studies; histograms and scatterplots, averages and standard deviations; measurement error, the normal approximation; correlation and regression; probability and chance variation; sampling, the Gallup Poll and Current Population Survey; tests of significance. Focus on understanding concepts rather than mathematical manipulation. No formal mathematical prerequisite. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,200. Session B: July 1 - August 2.

subject: SBS
title: Accelerated Social and Behavio...
long_title: Accelerated Social and Behavioral Foundations of Health
description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides students with an introduction to social and behavioral science issues that influence patterns of health and health care delivery. The focus is on the individual, interpersonal, community, and societal influences that must be taken into consideration when public health initiatives are developed and implemented. This course emphasizes the integration of research from the social and behavioral sciences with epidemiology and biomedical sciences.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: SCIE
title: Scientific Research: Process a...
description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative information. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,200. Course Dates: May 28-July27.

subject: SOCY
title: Foundations of Modern Social T...
description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology, with culture in capitalism and justice beliefs as a guiding theme. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,200. Session B: July 1 - August 2.

subject: SOCY
title: Social Networks and Society
description: Introduction to social networks. The role of social networks in contemporary society; network theory; basics of social network analysis; properties of network measures, matrices, and statistics. Theoretical concepts such as centrality and power, cohesion and embeddedness, structural holes, strong and weak ties, small worlds, and diffusion and contagion. Use of statistical approaches, social network analysis, and network visualization software. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,200. Session B: July 1 - August 2.

subject: SOCY
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Introduction to the study of sociology and modernity. Topics include the rise and transformations of capitalism; colonialism and empire; the linked advent of democracy and bureaucracy; the world-historical invention of the individual, and the modern and postmodern city. The course culminates in individualized student final projects, and includes a student-run class blog that discusses readings from classical and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,200. Session A: May 27-June 28.

subject: SOCY
title: Social Movements
description: As an introduction to sociological perspectives on social movements, this course is about how people act collectively to challenge the status quo of powerful political, economic, and cultural systems that resist change. Social movements that challenge such systems vary widely in terms of their group identities, social locations, strategies for action, particular demands, and tactics. In this course, we will consider a range of historical and contemporary case studies like the U.S. civil rights movement, the labor movement, “new” social movements in the 1960s (like the feminist and gay rights movements), the Tea Party and its challengers, and the Movement for Black Lives. We will approach these movements through concepts like: Solidarity, Organization, Mobilization, Identity, Resources, Framing, Collective Memory, Narrative, Networks and Organizations, Forms of Protest, and Performance. Though our case studies are mainly American, we will pay close attention to the ways that collective behavior and protest in the U.S. matters globally. And we will also consider how the internet and social media have changed social movements by investigating the roots and future prospects of movements represented by hashtags like #BlackLivesMatter and #MeToo. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,200. Session B: July 1 - August 2.

subject: SOCY
title: Society and Politics of North...
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: 5-week program: based in Ifrane, Morocco for 4-weeks followed by 1-week in Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib – Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya – has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. This crossroads remains strategically important with issues such as sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identities, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships current international concerns. This program provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Participants will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to have a homestay with a Moroccan family. Students choose AFST, GLBL, HIST, MMES, or SOCY credit. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Morocco and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the http://studyabroad.yale.edu/programs/society-politics-north-africa program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SOCY
title: Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: 5-week program: based in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. The course also includes several excursions in and around Dubrovnik, such as an afternoon in Cavtat and Konavle, a day trip to Kotor and Cetinje in Montenegro, a three-day visit to Sarajevo and Mostar in Bosnia and Herzegovina, an afternoon at the peninsula of Peljesac, and an afternoon on the island of Lokrum. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Dubrovnik and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the http://studyabroad.yale.edu/programs/history-culture-southeastern-europe program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: First course in an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" program. Students development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment is limited for each section. Application deadline: February 15.
requirements: Section 01: 30240 and Section 02: 302418-week program: based on the Yale campus (New Haven, CT) for 4-weeks followed by 4-weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 (Section 01: 30243 or Section 02: 30244) and SPAN S148 (Section 01: 30249 or Section 02: 30250). Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Bilbao and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the program page (https://studyabroad.yale.edu/programs/yale-summer-session-bilbao-intermediate) on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: Hi...
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
description: 8-week program: based on the Yale campus (New Haven, CT) for 4-weeks followed by 4-weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Part of an intensive "at-home-and-abroad" program. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Conducted in Spanish. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 & SPAN S140 (Bilbao). Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Bilbao and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: Hi...
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture

subject: SPAN
title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Tim...
long_title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
description: 8-week program: based on the Yale campus (New Haven, CT) for 3-weeks followed by 5-weeks in Quito, Ecuador. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Information is presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, movies, videos, music, visual arts). In the final three weeks of the program, students will work with Ecuadorian professors and students at the Universidad de las Américas on practical projects in one of the following areas: public health, environmental studies, or law and justice. Conducted in Spanish. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 & SPAN S140 (Quito). Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Quito and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SPAN
title: Advanced Spanish Language and...
long_title: Advanced Spanish Language and Andean Culture
description: 5-week program: based in Quito, Ecuador. This course is a language program that explores the culture and history of the Andean peoples through Ecuadorian and Latin American literature and films. The objective is for the students to understand, from a personal point of view, the complex relationships of the region within the context of today's modernity and rapid globalization of society. The students will practice expressing those ideas in written and oral forms. Prerequisite: SPAN 140 (Intermediate Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Quito and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SPAN
title: Language, Culture, and Society...
long_title: Language, Culture, and Society of Spain
description: 5-week program: based in Valencia, Spain. A language program that explores historical and contemporary issues in Spanish culture. Set in Valencia, a city founded by the Romans 2,000 years ago, this course aims to reflect on both Spanish ancient heritage and modernity. Key works of literature will foster discussion on a wide range of topics such as the environment, the Mediterranean trade, politics and religion. Students will integrate each week’s thematic content into real life observations to reflect on the fabric of Spanish society. Prerequisite: SPAN 140 (Intermediate Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Valencia and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the http://studyabroad.yale.edu/programs/language-culture-society-spain program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish for Reading
description: Online Course. Students acquire skills for reading Spanish-language texts of any difficulty with some fluency. Study of syntax and grammar; practice in close reading and translation of texts in different genres in the humanities. Yale doctoral students only. Tuition for Yale doctoral students covered by GSAS. Session B: June 24 - July 26.

subject: SUMR
title: Writing for Cross-Cultural Und...
description: Not for credit. Designed primarily for students whose first language is not English, this noncredit course offers practice in academic writing for students who need additional preparation for rigorous college writing courses. Special attention is paid to the conventions and practices of American academic writing. Students review the basics of English grammar and syntax while learning strategies of analysis, argument, and source use. Readings include short scholarly essays and excerpts from challenging and provocative longer works. Writing assignments include several one-page response papers and three longer academic essays. For college students and beyond. Enrollment limited to 15 students. Credit: 0. Tuition $2,230. Session B: July 1 - August 2.

subject: SUMR
title: Intensive English Program
description: Non-credit Certificate Program. The Intensive English Program is designed for international college students who want to improve their academic English language skills among a dynamic, diverse group of students. Students have the opportunity to develop the skills, fluency, and confidence needed to communicate effectively in English. Students will improve overall abilities in both spoken and written English, as well as understanding of the cultural diversity in the United States. Tuition: $4,600. Session B: July 1 – August 2.

subject: SUMR
title: Postgraduate Seminar
description: Non-credit Certificate Program. The Postgraduate Seminar is an intensive English program designed for international students who are attending or planning to attend graduate school in the U.S., or for mature or professional students who want to study English in a serious academic setting. The program will prepare students for the rigors of graduate school and improve their academic writing and speaking skills. Students will improve overall abilities in both spoken and written English, as well as their understanding of American academic culture. Tuition: $4,600. Session B: July 1 – August 2.

subject: SUMR
title: Teaching English as a Foreign...
long_title: Teaching English as a Foreign Language Seminar
description: Noncredit Certificate Program. This course is designed for English as a Foreign Language instructors who are interested in exploring American teaching methods. The course provides an examination and discussion of the basic principles of planning, implementing, and managing instruction in the EFL academic classroom. Through a variety of exploratory activities accompanied by careful readings on American culture and the philosophy of education, participants will form a strong foundation in attitudes, beliefs and values that are reflected in most American communicative approaches to language instruction. Please note that the TEFL Seminar is intended for non-native English speakers. Tuition: $4,600. Session B July 1 – August 2.

subject: SUMR
title: Business Seminar for Internati...
description: Non-credit Certificate Program. The Business Seminar is designed to prepare participants for professional life or graduate business study and help students compete in the world of business with English proficiency and experience. Participants will develop the communication skills needed to be competitive in global business and make international connections, gain cross-cultural understanding, and experience business case study analysis. Tuition: $5,400. Session B: July 1 – August 2.

subject: SUMR
title: Law Seminar for International...
description: Noncredit Certificate Program. The Law Seminar is an intensive introduction to the American legal system designed to prepare students to enter law school in the U.S.A. or work in the field of law in an international context, make international connections, learn about the American legal system and the legal English it requires. Tuition: $5,400. Session B: July 1 – August 2.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
description: 8-week program: based in Arusha, Tanzania. First course in an accelerated program for second-year language students involving refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Prerequisite: SWAH 120 (Beginning Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Arusha and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
description: 8-week program: based in Arusha, Tanzania. Second course in an accelerated program for second-year language students involving refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Prerequisite: SWAH 120 (Beginning Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S130. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Arusha and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: SWAH
title: Advanced Kiswahili
description: 8-week program: based in Arusha, Tanzania. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140 (Intermediate Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Arusha and all other program expenses beyond tuition. For further details, such as program costs, prerequisites, exact dates, credits, etc., visit the program page on the Yale Study Abroad website.

subject: THST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Chekov In Performance is a studio based exploration of the world of Anton Chekhov, focusing on acting technique through scene work as well as character analysis and development. The class will consist of close reading, rehearsal, research presentations, and occasional performance. This course is meant to promote truthful talking and listening, living moment to moment, a willingness to take risks regardless of outcome, playing from impulses in oneself and the text, personalizing circumstances and a better understanding of how to develop character. The course will use scenes from IVANOV, THE SEAGULL, UNCLE VANYA, THE THREE SISTERS and THE CHERRY ORCHARD to launch into an exploration of The Five Questions which stem from Stanislavsky’s work with Chekhov. While progressing through a sequence of short scenes and then longer scenes, the stress will be on understanding an acting technique that hinges upon an experiential exchange of energy between actors in pursuit of objectives. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,200. Session A: May 27 - June 28.

subject: WGSS
title: Women, Food, and Culture: Wome...
long_title: Women, Food, and Culture: Women, Food and Culture
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to the Peabody Museum, the Yale Farm, and the Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,200. Session A: May 27 - June 28.

subject: WGSS
title: Race and Gender in Asian Ameri...
long_title: Race and Gender in Asian American Popular Culture
description: Asian American popular culture through the shifting histories and ideologies that give it meaning. Considers the changing ideas of “Asian American” as a raced and gendered category that both represents and makes culture. Readings cover a variety of popular genres including film, television, music, and digital technologies. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,200. Session B: July 1 - August 2.

subject: WGSS
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Olympic Games: Ancient to Modern
description: Cancelled. Introduction to the history of the Olympic Games from antiquity to the present. The mythology of athletic events in ancient Greece and the ritual, political, and social ramifications of the actual competitions. The revival of the modern Olympic movement in 1896, the political investment of the Greek state at the time, and specific games as they illustrate the convergence of athletic cultures and sociopolitical transformations in the twentieth century. 1 Credit. Tuition $4,200. Session B: July 1 - August 2.
